author: quezacoa
content:
Dear eth2 team and community. I am running a node on a consumer grade notebook/hardware behind a usual ISP contract. Last night my router went down for a few hours until I restarted it.

First, I understand why the network needs penalties. With a linear penalty it is kind of ok If that happens IMO. Even a few days would be ok, e.g. if the ISP got problems, If the notebook burns etc. A node just has to be online about 50%+ of the time to not loose ETH.

I read about changing the penalty function from linear to quadratic. I guess that changes the situation. How fast will the penalty rise? Will a home run node owner have a problem if they sleep too long, or even need a few days to spin up a new node because they have hardware /ISP issues?

I believe the quadratic function is to be introduced because the home grade nodes should not be punished as strong if they have usual home grade problems such as an unreliable connection.

author: pietjepuk
content: The issue for per-validator-quadratic-penalties is still open, so I think this is all rather hypothetical still. Either way, I would imagine the quadratic drop-off to be similar to what is already there, e.g. reduction to 60% of balance when offline for ~36 days, 98% if offline for a week, or 99.96% if offline for a day.

author: quezacoa
content: Ah, thanks! I'll try to keep myself up to date. Which channel/blog/... should I monitor regarding this specific issue?

author: benjaminion
content:
The quadratic inactivity penalty applies only when the beacon chain is not finalising, which ought to be a very rare event - it has not happened yet on the Beacon Chain. Otherwise, the normal linear penalty remains if you are offline, and no change is planned to that. There is a change to the quadratic inactivity penalty in the Altair upgrade, which is to apply the quadratic penalty based on individual validators' uptime records rather than the crude distance since finality. The rationale is here: https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/issues/2125. It's basicaly no more punitive than the current scheme, and better for validators that are able to stay online.

In short:
  - Chain finalising, no change to offline penalties is planned.
  - Chain not finalising, penalties will be no worse than the current scheme, and smaller for those who continue validating.

author: quezacoa
content:
Thank you very much! 
One more question: there is a penalty for everyone if the chain is not finalizing, even for those who are not causing this event (those who continue validating)? I didn't expect that.

author: benjaminion
content: When the chain is not finalising, no attestation rewards are available, so no validator's balance increases. When a validator attests perfectly during this period, its balance does not decrease either: the rewards cancel out the penalties.

author: quezacoa
content: Ah okay, well I suppose that is logical as no new blocks are generated, this there are no rewards.

author: jgm
content: There was a separate discussion about changing the ejection balance to a much higher boundary, e.g. 30 Ether.  As far as I remember there were no arguments against it, but it didn't go anywhere (possibly because there was no obvious number to select).

author: pietjepuk
content:
Well, if as <@!573787335796326400> said it's only for when there's no finalization, it'd take almost **2 years** to drop 10% when the network is stable. I would hardly call that excessive punishment of those in "less stable countries". [0]

As far as penalization during non-finalization is concerned, the security of the networks comes first. Non-finalization is expected to be a very rare occurrence, and in that case it makes perfect sense to me to more quickly draw down the balance (to get back to finalization) without hurting those that perform their duties well. 

[0]  There might be something to be said for auto-initializing an exit/withdrawal to the eth1 address in case of 0x01 withdrawal credentials if the balance drops 10% or so. As far as raising the ejection balance is concerned (that <@!144468805697929216> mentions): https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/issues/2108

author: potuz
content: As new validators are onboarded, getting to 16 becomes almost impossible. In fact not only there aren't arguments against 30 that I can think of, but there are good arguments to increase this limit. Even from a security perspective. If we do have some sort of eclipse attack that manages to stop finalization by killing a bunch of nodes, exiting them at 30 not only protects their money as it protects the network as a whole

author: sma4321
content: perhaps a more optimal time to consider this is post-merge, for the fork where withdrawals are enabled, because at that time, anyone who may get ejected due to the consequences of external events has a far lower barrier to immediately reentering the validator pool.
